thread.title: Woman found dead in recycling bin 'was removing clothes when stool collapsed leaving her dangling from broken arm'
thread.title_full: Woman found dead in recycling bin 'was removing clothes when stool collapsed leaving her dangling from broken arm' - Mirror Online

author: mirror.co.uk
title: Woman found dead in recycling bin 'was removing clothes when stool collapsed leaving her dangling from broken arm'
text:
Woman found dead in recycling bin 'was removing clothes when stool collapsed leaving her dangling from broken arm' Judith Permar was removing items from a clothing donation bin at 2am when the freak accident happened, friends said   Share   Comments By Steve Robson 05:18, 9 FEB 2017 Updated 05:20, 9 FEB 2017 News Permar was using a step stool to reach into the bin when it collapsed beneath her (Photo: Facebook)   Share   Comments Get daily   A woman was killed by a recycling bin when the footstool she was using collapsed and left her dangling from a broken arm, it is believed.
The horrific circumstances of Judith Permar's death have been pieced together after police found her body in odd circumstances at 8.30am on Monday morning, in the small town of Natalie, Pennysylvania.
The 56-year-old was discovered already dead with one arm stuck in the drop-off box of a clothing recycling bin.
Due to the height of the drop-box, Judith was suspended from the ground.
Permar was unable to remove her arm from the drop-off box after it got stuck (Photo: (LUCENTIUS/GETTY IMAGES/ISTOCKPHOTO)) Bags filled with clothes and shoes that had been pulled from the bin lay on the ground and her black Hummer was parked up nearby with the engine still running.
Friends said it is believed she had been using a footstool to reach into the bin and retrieve clothes at 2am when it collapsed.
She suffered a broken arm and wrist and died from "blunt force trauma" and "hypothermia", according to a coroner's report.
Police have ruled the death accidental.
When asked why Judith would have been retrieving items from the bin, Mount Carmel Township Police Chief Brian Hollenbush told the New York Post: "It wasn’t something that I would expect to be seeing."
He said the force had received reports of a woman taking items from the same bin in November.
Mr Hollenbush, who knew Judith personally, described her as a "nice woman".
Her daughter, Angela Minnig, took to Facebook to remember Permar following her tragic passing.
“It was very sudden and our family will learn to cope with the loss of such an amazing Wife, Mother, Sister and Friend,” she wrote.
“She was such a fun loving person and we know it would mean the world to her to say ‘See you Again.’”
It is not the first time a person has died after becoming trapped in a recycling bin.
In 2014, a 68-year-old man was found dead with his head and arms trapped in a donation bin in Mallorca.
Police believed the OAP was out shopping and decided to throw some old newspapers away, but accidentally dropped something else inside the bin.
When he reached in to fetch the item, he became trapped when the lid flapped shut on his head.
In 2010, a homeless man died in Newham, East london, after falling into a clothes recycling bin.
It was believed Dainius Kankas had been trying to help himself to clothing when he became wedge headfirst and suffocated.
